meanings.definition: A device for keeping the mouth open or closed.
meanings.sent1: The dentist used a gag to keep the patient's mouth open during the procedure.
meanings.sent2: She removed the gag from the box and examined its design.
meanings.sent3: The clown's oversized gag made everyone laugh at the circus.
meanings.sent4: The old movie had a scene where the villain used a gag to silence the hero.
meanings.sent5: The bright red color of the gag made it easy to spot in the drawer.

meanings.sent1: He started to gag on the strong smell coming from the kitchen.
meanings.sent2: The unpleasant taste made her gag and spit out the food.
meanings.sent3: The comedian pretended to gag on a fake banana peel for a funny skit.
meanings.sent4: The thought of public speaking made her gag with nervousness.
meanings.sent5: The pungent odor of the garbage made him gag as he took out the trash.

meanings.sent1: The kids played a funny gag on their teacher by hiding his chalk.
meanings.sent2: The comedy show was full of hilarious gags that had the audience laughing.
meanings.sent3: The classic gag of the whoopee cushion never fails to make people smile.
meanings.sent4: The birthday card had a silly gag printed inside that made her chuckle.
meanings.sent5: The clown's colorful wig was part of his signature gag during performances.

meanings.sent1: The kidnapper used a cloth to gag the victim and stop any screams.
meanings.sent2: She had to gag her friend to keep the surprise party a secret.
meanings.sent3: The noisy parrot was gagged during the meeting to avoid interruptions.
meanings.sent4: The villain threatened to gag the witness if they spoke out against him.
meanings.sent5: The teacher had to gag the class clown to maintain order in the classroom.
